Insight Data Analysis

Insight Data Analysis

Understand the Dataset Structure:

library(readxl)

library (ggplot2)

Visualizations:

Use ggplot2 to visualize relationships and distributions, for example:

ggplot(airbnb_data, aes(x=price)) + geom_histogram(bins=50)

ggplot(airbnb_data, aes(x=neighbourhood_group, y=price)) + geom_boxplot()

Check for Missing Values:

sapply(airbnb_data, function(x) sum(is.na(x)))
                            id                           name 
                             0                             26 
                       host_id                      host_name 
                             0                             22 
           neighbourhood_group                  neighbourhood 
                             0                              0 
                      latitude                      longitude

                         10052                          10052 
calculated_host_listings_count               availability_365 
                             0                              0

Data Cleaning and Preprocessing

  • Handle Missing Values: Impute or remove missing values depending on their impact.

  • Feature Selection: Choose relevant features for your model. For example, predicting price based on room_type, number_of_reviews, etc.

  • Encoding Categorical Variables: Use one-hot encoding for categorical variables.

  • Data Transformation: Normalize or scale numerical features if necessary.

    Building a Linear Regression Model

    Simple Linear Regression:

    model_simple <- lm(price ~ number_of_reviews, data=airbnb_data)
summary(model_simple)
    
Call:
lm(formula = price ~ number_of_reviews, data = airbnb_data)

Residuals:
   Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
-158.7  -84.1  -42.7   24.6 9842.6 

Coefficients:
                   Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)       158.73718    1.22396  129.69   <2e-16 ***
number_of_reviews  -0.25850    0.02435  -10.62   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 239.9 on 48893 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.0023,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.002279 
F-statistic: 112.7 on 1 and 48893 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

Multiple Linear Regression:

model_multiple <- lm(price ~ neighbourhood_group + room_type + number_of_reviews, data=airbnb_data)
summary(model_multiple)

Call:
lm(formula = price ~ neighbourhood_group + room_type + number_of_reviews, 
    data = airbnb_data)

Residuals:
   Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
-245.4  -63.5  -23.9   11.5 9935.3 

Coefficients:
                                   Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)                       167.07516    7.12561  23.447  < 2e-16 ***
neighbourhood_groupBrooklyn        21.41440    7.15663   2.992  0.00277 ** 
neighbourhood_groupManhattan       78.34453    7.15926  10.943  < 2e-16 ***

neighbourhood_groupStaten Island   13.77961   13.79731   0.999  0.31794    
room_typePrivate room            -111.38012    2.14205 -51.997  < 2e-16 ***
room_typeShared room             -135.13695    6.91869 -19.532  < 2e-16 ***
number_of_reviews                  -0.21472    0.02338  -9.182  < 2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 230 on 48887 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.08318,   Adjusted R-squared:  0.08304 
F-statistic: 633.6 on 7 and 48887 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

Model Diagnostics

  • Check assumptions of linear regression such as linearity, homoscedasticity, and normality of residuals.

Model Validation

  • Use cross-validation to assess model performance.

Model Improvement

  • Explore different combinations of features.

  • Consider transforming features or using polynomial terms for non-linear relationships.

Conclusion

This process offers a systematic approach to building a linear regression model using the NYC Airbnb dataset. Itâ€™s essential to understand each step thoroughly for robust model development and accurate insights.
